CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: In order to understand the influence of ratios between the donor polymer and acceptor , thicknesses of the photoactive layer , and the annealing temperatures on the photovoltaic properties , the current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices at different ratios , thicknesses , and annealing temperatures are shown in Figures S4 , S5 , and S6 , respectively. The resulting photovoltaic data are summarized in Tables S1 , S2 , and S3 , respectively. The optimized ratio of 1 : 1.3 , thickness of 80 nm , and annealing temperature of 120 °C were obtained. In these optimized conditions , two typical devices using PC71BM and PC61BM as acceptor exhibited the following typical J-V characteristics in Figure 2 under 1000 W m -2 air mass 1.5 global ( AM 1.5G ) illumination. Device parameters , such as J SC , V OC , FF , and PCE are deduced from the J-V characteristics and summarized in Table 3. It is clear that the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices exhibited better photovoltaic properties as compared to the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC61BM - based devices , which can be attributed to the stronger absorption of PC71BM than PC61BM in the visible region from 440 to 530 nm , as shown in Figure 1b. A maximal PCE of 4.89% with an V OC of 0.84 V , a J SC of 10.04 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 56.0% was achieved for the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices. To our best knowledge , the recorded maximum PCE and FF levels here are higher than those for the previous side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased PSCs. Furthermore , these PSCs based on the side - chain D-A polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S presented significantly improved device performance over those PSCs using a mainchain D-A polymer of PDPP - BDT or PBDTPP-OR as donor. 7 Figure 3 shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) curve of the device with the PBDT-TDPP-S : PC71BM blend. The EQE values are about 45% with a broad response from 300 to 750 nm , which are consistent with the optical absorption profile in Figure 1b. According to the EQE curve and the solar irradiation spectrum , the integral current density value of the device is 9.70 mA cm^-2 . The difference between the measured J SC and the integral current density values is within 3% . It indicates that our photovoltaic measurement is accurate and reliable. The moderate EQE reported here implies some potential for further enhancement in J SC as well. To assess the charge transport properties for the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend used as photoactive layer , we measured the J-V characteristics of single charge carrier devices at room temperature and applied space-charge-limited-current ( SCLC ) model to extract the charge carrier mobility.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| PC71BM |
| PC61BM |
| PDPP-BDT |
| PBDTPP-OR |

Note: The material names are presented precisely as they appear in the original paragraph.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PBDT-TDPP-S |
| PC71BM |
| PC61BM |

The following entities do not clearly refer to "Material name" and were removed:

* "PDPP-BDT"
* "PBDTPP-OR"

The remaining entities are presented in the table above, precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: In order to understand the influence of ratios between the donor polymer and acceptor , thicknesses of the photoactive layer , and the annealing temperatures on the photovoltaic properties , the current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices at different ratios , thicknesses , and annealing temperatures are shown in Figures S4 , S5 , and S6 , respectively. The resulting photovoltaic data are summarized in Tables S1 , S2 , and S3 , respectively. The optimized ratio of 1 : 1.3 , thickness of 80 nm , and annealing temperature of 120 °C were obtained. In these optimized conditions , two typical devices using PC71BM and PC61BM as acceptor exhibited the following typical J-V characteristics in Figure 2 under 1000 W m -2 air mass 1.5 global ( AM 1.5G ) illumination. Device parameters , such as J SC , V OC , FF , and PCE are deduced from the J-V characteristics and summarized in Table 3. It is clear that the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices exhibited better photovoltaic properties as compared to the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC61BM - based devices , which can be attributed to the stronger absorption of PC71BM than PC61BM in the visible region from 440 to 530 nm , as shown in Figure 1b. A maximal PCE of 4.89% with an V OC of 0.84 V , a J SC of 10.04 mA cm^-2 , and a FF of 56.0% was achieved for the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices. To our best knowledge , the recorded maximum PCE and FF levels here are higher than those for the previous side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased PSCs. Furthermore , these PSCs based on the side - chain D-A polymer of PBDT-TDPP-S presented significantly improved device performance over those PSCs using a mainchain D-A polymer of PDPP - BDT or PBDTPP-OR as donor. 7 Figure 3 shows the external quantum efficiency ( EQE ) curve of the device with the PBDT-TDPP-S : PC71BM blend. The EQE values are about 45% with a broad response from 300 to 750 nm , which are consistent with the optical absorption profile in Figure 1b. According to the EQE curve and the solar irradiation spectrum , the integral current density value of the device is 9.70 mA cm^-2 . The difference between the measured J SC and the integral current density values is within 3% . It indicates that our photovoltaic measurement is accurate and reliable. The moderate EQE reported here implies some potential for further enhancement in J SC as well. To assess the charge transport properties for the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend used as photoactive layer , we measured the J-V characteristics of single charge carrier devices at room temperature and applied space-charge-limited-current ( SCLC ) model to extract the charge carrier mobility.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| J-V characteristics |
| current density |
| voltage |
| annealing temperature |
| thickness |
| ratio |
| J SC |
| V OC |
| FF |
| PCE |
| EQE |
| integral current density |
| charge carrier mobility |

Note:

* J-V characteristics refer to the current-voltage characteristics of a photovoltaic device.
* current density and voltage are properties of the device under test.
* annealing temperature, thickness, and ratio refer to the parameters of the photoactive layer.
* J SC, V OC, FF, and PCE are parameters deduced from the J-V characteristics and summarized in Table 3.
* EQE (external quantum efficiency) is a measure of the efficiency of the device in converting incident light into electrical current.
* integral current density is the total current density integrated over the entire spectrum of incident light.
* charge carrier mobility is a measure of the ability of charge carriers (electrons or holes) to move through the material.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Property name of material" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Name |
| --- |
| J-V characteristics |
| current density |
| voltage |
| annealing temperature |
| thickness |
| ratio |
| J SC |
| V OC |
| FF |
| PCE |

Note:

* J-V characteristics, current density, voltage, annealing temperature, thickness, and ratio are properties of the material.
* J SC, V OC, FF, and PCE are parameters deduced from the J-V characteristics and summarized in Table 3.

The following entities do not clearly refer to "Property name of material" and were removed:

* EQE (external quantum efficiency)
* integral current density
* charge carrier mobility

Paragraph: In order to understand the influence of ratios between the donor polymer and acceptor , thicknesses of the photoactive layer , and the annealing temperatures on the photovoltaic properties , the current density - voltage ( J-V ) characteristics of the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM - based devices at different ratios , thicknesses , and annealing temperatures are shown in Figures S4 , S5 , and S6 , respectively. To our best knowledge , the recorded maximum PCE and FF levels here are higher than those for the previous side - chain D-A conjugated copolymersbased PSCs. To assess the charge transport properties for the PBDT-TDPP-S:PC71BM blend used as photoactive layer , we measured the J-V characteristics of single charge carrier devices at room temperature and applied space-charge-limited-current ( SCLC ) model to extract the charge carrier mobility.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 1:1.3 | Optimized ratio of donor polymer (PBDT-TDPP-S) to acceptor (PC71BM) |
| 80 nm | Optimized thickness of photoactive layer |
| 120°C | Optimized annealing temperature |
| 1000 W/m² | Irradiance under AM 1.5G illumination |
| 4.89% | Maximal PCE (photovoltaic conversion efficiency) |
| 0.84 V | VOC (open-circuit voltage) |
| 10.04 mA/cm² | JSC (short-circuit current density) |
| 56.0% | FF (fill factor) |
| 45% | External quantum efficiency (EQE) |
| 300-750 nm | Broad response range of EQE |
| 9.70 mA/cm² | Integral current density value |
| 3% | Difference between measured JSC and integral current density values |

Note: The units for the properties are provided in the original paragraph, and they are included in the table for clarity.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Value of material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 1:1.3 | Optimized ratio of donor polymer (PBDT-TDPP-S) to acceptor (PC71BM) |
| 80 nm | Optimized thickness of photoactive layer |
| 120°C | Optimized annealing temperature |

* "1000 W/m²" (irradiance under AM 1.5G illumination)

* "300-750 nm" (broad response range of EQE)
* "9.70 mA/cm²" (integral current density value)
* "3%" (difference between measured JSC and integral current density values)
